ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar once a week

While class was mostly discussion over Zoom or collaborative workshopping of translations we were also given other tools to use outside of class like short videos or examination of subtitling in films.
Seminar style meetings (11 students plus professor) once per week

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about the significance of translation and about how to translate. This course challenged me to write and think creatively.
Learned that translation is an art form (truly!!!), not a mathematical or scientific process.

I learned so much about the specifics of translation, from sentence structure, punctuation, and formatting to literary devices, sonority, and choosing good titles. I have become more conscious of the balance between efficiency and style and now feel confident approaching prose of any genre.
I learned how to translate, how to interpret literature to a degree, how to read translations, how to edit writing, and I think how to read literature in general.

French to English translation. The course is conducted entirely in English but a good grasp on reading in French is obviously necessary (good English writing skills are probably more important). How to use dictionaries and thesauruses well, how to analyze context and move from transcribing to interpretation, etc. Nice course!!
I learned the basics about French translation and applied those lessons in weekly translation assignments that I received feedback on.
I learned how to develop a faithful translation, but also how a translation can be a work in its own right, we do this by focusing on author style, double meanings, translation of "on," etc.
I learned that translation is an art and the work thats produced is in many cases a work within its own right.
I certainly improved my French reading ability as well as the way that I read and translate French in my head in general.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Each week, there is a new short piece to be translated, which is workshopped in class. The final draft is then due the following week. I really liked this format because I was new to translation and it allowed me to ask questions and gain insight from my peers and from Prof. Waters.
Strengths: solid workload. Consistent. Weaknesses: Didn't always know what was expected for the next week, because there was no specific syllabus posted.

The strength of this course was how closely everyone worked together as we revised our work in small groups. We all learned from each other and grew to be both more critical of our choices and more confident in our instincts, if that makes sense. The pieces were also well-chosen, and I was surprised by how valuable I found the translation analysis assignment to be.
I thought that this was an excellent course.
A little more clarity with respect to grades would have been good along the way. Besides that, all excellent!
I really appreciated how much hands-on translation experience we got.

I only wish we had more opportunities to practice speaking French in this class, while I read a lot of French I didn't use oral skills as much as I would have liked. However, this is understandable for a translation course I think this actually more reflective of the unfortunate fact that a lot of upper level French courses don't seem to be taught in French, aside from a weekly section.

I loved being able to break up in groups abs review a translated work together. It helps to see how differently others could translate a similar piece. I also liked the larger group discussions which afforded us huge opportunities to ask the professor clarifying questions. The variety of the assigned readings was also super helpful and allowed us to work different translation muscles.
I know this isnt within the syllabus of this course, but I wouldve loved to speak a bit of French and maybe even attempt to translate in English piece into French.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved this class. Prof. Waters made room for COVID in a healthy way and really appreciated our attention every class, but also didn't just let us off the hook.

Dividing us into groups to discuss our translations allowed for a comfortable space for us to voice our opinions, instead of having to do this in front of the whole class. This allowed for a greater chance to do the exploration necessary to acquire a new skill.
All good, v well managed
The online format in which assignments and relevant files were posted on Canvas worked fine for this course.

I really appreciated how much Prof. Waters emphasized group work and collaboration, given that this is a relatively longer class than others she understood how it is important not to talk at students and instead she invited us to learn from her knowledge of translation but also share our many ideas with our peers.
Seminar style class format was effective for this particular course. Breaking up into smaller groups to go over translated works was effective.
We did breakout rooms to go over our work which I really enjoyed and found useful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! Prof Waters is such a lovely teacher and translation is so much fun! I had never taken a class like this before and it was fun to try something new and exercise a new part of my brain.
Yes!! If you love French and are interested in translating, take it.

I would recommend this class to anyone remotely interested in translation. If you like reading and writing and can appreciate the subtleties of language and art of crafting sentences, take it - you will learn a lot and have a great time doing it.
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. It was enjoyable and inspired growth.
Yes! Spend a semester in the company of some excellent, eccentric French writers. Prof Waters is kind, funny, brilliant, great
Yes. You'll gain a solid understanding of the key difficulties of translating French prose into English and how to work through these challenges.

I think if you are studying literature or French and are on the translation track this is obviously a necessary course, but even if you are not pursuing this field but have a knowledge and interest in French I highly recommend the course. Translation, for those who want to pursue the subject,  becomes like a creative writing class and an exploration of different author styles, and for those who  don't want to necessarily pursue this field, translation is like a fun brain exercise.

Yes, even if youre not interested in translating work, it can still be helpful in understanding translated work. This course also offers insight on what really goes on in the course of translating works and makes you look at such work with deeper appreciation.
